thread.title: How Rough helped ‘hurt’ Hawk land at Dees
thread.title_full: How Rough helped ‘hurt’ Hawk land at Dees

title: How Rough helped ‘hurt’ Hawk land at Dees
text:
Source: FOX SPORTS MELBOURNE recruit Jordan Lewis has opened up on the pain of not feeling “wanted” by Hawthorn and the crucial role best mate Jarryd Roughead played in helping him find a new club. 
Lewis, who won four premierships with the Hawks, is set to play his first game for the Demons this weekend against St Kilda after he was sensationally traded from Hawthorn during last year’s exchange period. 
Speaking on Fox Footy’s AFL 360 , Lewis admitted the pain of rejection was originally tough to take, but on the eve of Round 1 he doesn’t regret his decision. 
“I was hurt,” an honest Lewis said. 
“Any situation where you don’t feel like you’re wanted, I think there’s always a dent in your pride. 
“But I look at it as if maybe it’s a blessing in disguise and I do have an opportunity to go to another club and rejuvenate myself.

“It’s been fantastic, I’ve loved it — and if I had the decision again knowing what I know now, I still would’ve made the same decision.” 
Lewis insisted that he wasn’t “pushed out” by the Hawks, emphasising that he still had the opportunity to stay if he wanted to as he was contracted. 
He said he was grateful that he was involved in the entire decision-making process with Hawthorn. 
“I think they saw an opportunity where I could potentially get a career somewhere else,” Lewis said. 
“We’ve seen in the past other clubs probably haven’t dealt with it the best they possibly could and players finish their career and have got nowhere to go, even though they think they can still play on. Jarryd Roughead and Jordan Lewis after Hawthorn’s 2015 flag. Picture: Michael Klein Source: News Corp Australia 
“That’s the way I feel about it, I’m not going to sugar-coat it.” 
Lewis admitted it was a “bizarre” feeling to be sitting in the Fox Footy studios in a Melbourne polo shirt after spending most of 2016 in a Hawthorn top under no trade speculation. 
“I still haven’t had time to look back on it, because it has been me that was in the decision,” Lewis said. 
“I don’t see mine as a massive thing because I’ve been involved in the process. 
“I had to do it in a way where the media wouldn’t find out, because if they found out that I was searching for a club then it would’ve become bigger than it should’ve been. I wanted to do it my way, research my own way and inquire my own way.” 
Throughout that process, Lewis kept Roughead in the loop as the tall forward continued his recovery from a melanoma scare. 
And while Roughead, who has previously shown some interest in list management, wasn’t originally vocal about the specific club he should go to, he still played a key role in supporting Lewis. 
But when asked whether Roughead was an advocate for the Demons, Lewis said his best mate gave his blessing come decision time. 
“As a mate of mine I wanted him to be involved in the process,” Lewis said. 
“I didn’t want him to pick up the newspaper and read that I’ve left. I wanted to him to be over it throughout the process. “ 
“I think from afar, what we’ve seen with Melbourne last year is that certainly they’ve improved, there’s stability in the club now. 
“Speaking with Todd (Viney) and delving a bit deeper into that before I made the decision, it was evident that they were on the right path.” 
Lewis said he couldn’t wait to see Roughead make his AFL return for Hawthorn on Saturday night against Essendon, but added he was disappointed he couldn’t attend the game as the Melbourne-St Kilda clash finishes just minutes before the Hawks-Bombers clash commences, 
“It’s just one of those things that we didn’t expect. We thought he’d still be going through treatment at this stage,” Lewis said. 
“For him to put that aside and captain the club in his first game back, it’s an unbelievable story.”
